Title: Risk, balanced skills and entrepreneurship

Abstract: This paper proposes that risk aversion encourages individuals to invest in balanced skill profiles, making them more likely to become entrepreneurs. Abstract: One of the more interesting trends in organizational ethnography is the increasing allowance made for self-reflection in published field accounts. Using field notes from a 199-day full-time ethnography of Cambridge University's preparations for the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race, it argues that dreams are a useful resource for reflexivity. Title: Post-dominant design technological shift: Empirical analysis of subsystem-level evolution of complex product
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: Using the systems view of the product, I argue that the emergence of a dominant design does not necessarily lead to a period of incremental innovation and subsequent product discontinuity; rather, firms shift focus of innovation to another part of the product at a subsystem level following the emergence of a dominant design. I carefully performed both the historical analysis of technology evolution and detailed patent content analysis for the automotive emissions control system and empirically confirmed that there was significant shift in the focus of innovation to another subsystem, electronics, following the emergence of a catalyst-based dominant design. Moreover, the rate of innovation during the post-dominant design period is found to be lower than that of the pre-dominant design period. Findings of this study highlight the importance of the "match complexity" view of researchers that emphasizes system integration capability for managing contemporary complex technology evolution.

Title: Organizational response to public attacks of rivals: A categorization perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: When a focal firm's rivals are publicly attacked for an alleged violation of industry norms, a risk of contamination spreads to all members associated with the industry category. The more intense the attacks on rivals, the more likely audiences will stereotype the industry category and generalize to all members of that industry category the negative attributes implied by the attacks. In this paper, we suggest that the intensity of the public attacks of rivals leads to a greater likelihood that a focal firm will respond to avoid contamination. As the risk of generalization increases, firms tend to dissociate themselves from the tainted industry category by altering their business portfolio. They do so in relation to their own degree of prototypicality (i.e., how much they resemble the average member of the tainted category). We use panel data on the global defense industry between 1996 and 2007 to test our hypotheses. Results support our claims that (1) the public attacks of rivals drive a firm's dissociation from the targeted industry and (2) this dissociation is attenuated for less prototypical firms.

Title: Tie loss and gain during management transitions

Abstract: This study concerns tie loss and gain during management transitions. Title: Open source, open innovation, open communities: What drives the performance of "open"?
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: Despite its economic and social impact, open collaboration (OC) remains a puzzle. Here we show that OC - in software, science, and elsewhere - is a robust engine for innovation and production, one that performs well even in unfavorable conditions and is likely to continue expanding. Its emergence and growth can inform organizational theory. "Open" is booming. Open source software, a well-known harbinger, has progressed to mainstream. Once the domain of hobbyists and hackers, it has gained acceptance with corporations and governments. The Apache webserver and the Linux and Android operating systems have become commonplace, creating billions of dollars in economic value (e.g., European Commission, 2006). Yet "open" has progressed beyond software. Similar patterns of innovation and production - which we called Open Collaboration (OC) - have flourished in a variety of innovation and production activities, for goods and services (Baldwin & Von Hippel, 2011; Benkler, 2011; von Hippel, 2005b). The free encyclopedia Wikipedia, once mocked as "faith based", has come to match the quality of its primary for-profit rival (Giles, 2005). Science has been progressing by enlisting thousands of volunteers, each contributing just a fraction of a solution, to make discoveries and solve problems too immense for traditional organizations (Benkler, 2004; Partha, 1994). Similar patterns that are labeled by the adjectival "open" have emerged in medicine (Ort et al., 2009; Rai, 2005), engineering ("open design") and biotechnology (Henkel & Maurer, 2007, 2009). More generally, the Open Science movement aims to transform scientific research and publishing by dispersing authority and expanding sharing (Lin, 2012). In everyday life, strangers collaborate, answer questions, and solve problems in user-to-user forums (Lakhani & von Hippel, 2003), mailing lists (Jarvenpaa & Majchrzak, 2008) and online communities (Faraj & Johnson, 2010). People also collaborate in peer-to-peer networks, where they share files (sometimes illegally, see Levine, 2001) and bandwidth, leading to free services such as Skype (Benkler, 2006:83-87). These patterns of innovation, production, and collaboration have been noted by scholars. Our inquiry and model apply broadly to cover a variety of phenomena, including Open Collaborative Innovation (Baldwin & Von Hippel, 2011), Peer Production (Benkler, 2002), Community Based Innovation System (Franke & Shah, 2003), and some instances of Open Innovation (West & Gallagher, 2006), Transaction-Free Zones (Baldwin, 2008), Collaborative communities (Adler, Kwon, & Heckscher, 2008), and Electronic Networks of Practice or Online Communities (Faraj, Jarvenpaa, & Majchrzak, 2011; Kollock, 1999; Wasko & Faraj, 2005). Despite its social and economic impact and the scholarly interest it drew, OC remains a puzzle. Here, we trace the boundaries that define it. Then, we draw on recent evidence on human cooperation to answer a fundamental question about the phenomenon: why people share the fruits of cooperation with non-contributors. The answer is related to cooperativeness, the tendency of participants to cooperate, which is one factor that affects the performance of OC. We join cooperativeness with other factors found in theory and evidence: need heterogeneity, or diversity of the participants' needs and wants, and the extent to which the shared goods are rival, where one's consumption interferes with another's (aka subtractable, Hess & Ostrom, 2006). To test the performance of OC, we combine the three elements - cooperativeness, need heterogeneity, rivalry - in an agent-based model. Because we envision OC as a general system for innovation and production, the model uses a fundamental measure of economic performance: efficiency in turning inputs to outputs through collaboration. The results are counterintuitive: OC can thrive even in seemingly inhospitable environments, reaching much broadly than currently assumed or observed. It performs robustly even when cooperators are a fraction of participants, free riders are present, goods are rival, or participant needs are homogenous. The results suggest what affects the performance of OC, but - equally important - what does not. The findings imply growth and spread of OC into new domains, and they can also inform the discussion on new organizational forms, collaborative and communal (e.g., Adler et al., 2008; Benkler, 2011; Faraj et al., 2011; Heckscher & Adler, 2006). It suggests that human efforts can be harnessed in previously unthought-of ways.

Title: Technology and context: A sociomateriality perspective on technology enabled change
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: Most previous work on the topic of IT-enabled change has drawn a black box around the technology artifact, and instead focused attention on the social and organizational processes that emerge as a result of the adoption of new technology (Leonardi and Barley, 2008). As a result, little is ever known about the constitutive interaction between the technology and the work processes that combine to generate performance outcomes across diverse settings. Using within and cross case analyses, this study seeks to fill this gap in our current understanding of ITenabled change by investigating the following research question: How do the material properties of RFID based inventory management systems and the work practices of clinicians interact to impact performance outcomes in urgent care contexts? In order to address these issues, we adopt a sociomateriality framework that will be used to guide our data collection and analysis.

Title: Orchestrating complex product development: Reducing rework hazards of architectural mismatches
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: The literature on innovation management has established the advantages for product development performance when product architecture and organizational architecture are matched appropriately. The authors observed a modular supply chain comprising an aircraft OEM and several suppliers as their process oscillated, causing rework and delays. We hypothesize that this situation is analogous to a classical dynamic feedback system with time delay and that the process can be improved by applying known methods from Control Theory applicable to such situations. To test these strategies, we developed a computer agent model and a simulation game. Our agent model and simulation experiments replicated the behavior of experienced engineers and managers using prior suboptimal strategies and revised ones motivated by control theory. We discuss the managerial implications, including improved incentives and process management techniques.

Title: Inter-team knowledge sharing: The variegated effects of context and when lobbying can help
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: This paper considers the contingent effects of context on the relationship between upward lobbying and knowledge sharing in organizations. Existing research has indicated that organizational groups frequently rely on lobbying tactics to acquire knowledge and that this has significant performance effects. But how the effectiveness of such tactics depend on the task context is not clear. In R&D teams in the pharmaceutical industry, I investigated the effects of upward lobbying on knowledge acquisition in contexts involving different kinds of knowledge and with varying levels of inter-group competition. In contexts of high competition, upward lobbying was positively associated with acquisition of codified knowledge, but it had no effect on non-codified knowledge. In contexts of low competition, upward lobbying was negatively associated with acquisition of non-codified knowledge, and had no effect on codified knowledge. Furthermore, I found that acquisition of both codified and non-codified knowledge was positively associated with performance. The findings highlight the importance of context in understanding how political behavior can help, or hurt, knowledge acquisition and performance in organizations.

Title: Electronic Human Resource Management: Four decades of empirical evidence
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: This paper reviews four decades of e-HRM (Electronic Human Resource Management) academic literature. Such a review is timely and relevant since e-HRM is one of the most implemented applications in organizations (Lee, 2011). The analysis of 299 articles reveals that one stream of e-HRM literature, dominated by IT-oriented scholars, investigates the essential factors to consider when implementing e-HRM technology. A second stream, dominated by organizational (and pure HRM) scholars, focuses on studying the consequences of e-HRM systems. The authors synthesize and discuss the full range of empirically studied factors, aiming to heighten awareness about the impact of e-HRM systems on management decisions and their consequences for organizations and employees. While technological factors were assumed to be most relevant for effectively automating personnel departments in the 70's and 80's, it was subsequently recognized that managing people and organizational factors was of vital importance for successful implementations. Next to positive operational consequences of e-HRM systems, relational and transformational consequences continue to gain importance. This review shows how e-HRM research is evolving from merely declaring assumptions towards enhancing the rigor of its conceptual and empirical basis.

Title: The impact of language barriers on shared mental models in multinational teams
Source title: Academy of Management 2012 Annual Meeting, AOM 2012
Abstract: Large corporations increasingly use multinational teams (MNTs) to integrate their global operations. To perform their complex tasks efficiently, team members need to develop shared mental models (SMMs), i.e. an organized understanding of the knowledge base they are sharing. However, the heterogeneity of MNT members presents a substantial challenge to SMM formation. While previous research has investigated the influence of different diversity factors on SMMs, the impact of language differences has been neglected so far. To address this important gap we investigate in depth how different elements of the language barrier impede the formation of different types of SMMs. Our findings integrate linguistic and psychological theories with management studies and complement our understanding of the antecedents of SMMs in MNTs. This is of crucial importance since SMMs have been established as important prerequisites for team performance.
